title: The Block 2019 episode 45 recap: judges slam ‘lazy’ balconies
text:
To enter the world of The Block is to enter a world in which a judge can describe a balcony with insufficient furniture as “a tragedy” without a trace of irony.

A world where an interior designer can suffer a bout of rage over a fake plant, and call a couple who worked a 70 hour week to finish two veranda’s “lazy”.

RELATED

Has Mel had enough of her ‘worst boyfriend’

Mark and Mitch set to auction their Bondi pad

I guess the judges had to create a bit of drama this week — because the spaces the teams were delivering this week were identical in terms of paint colour, fretwork, balustrades, flooring and ceiling, and that doesn’t make for great renovation TV.

All the teams could really do for the win was choose the right furniture and put it in the right place. And given several teams chose the same furniture as well, it was hard to tell these balconies apart.

The aforementioned tragedy belonged to Jesse and Mel, who said all along they wouldn’t be busting a boiler to win this week. Real estate agent Jesse’s opinion was the level two and three balconies wouldn’t do much to sell the houses, so they decided to keep their powder and their cash for the final three rooms.

“You’re not going to be taking your family through your bedroom to have a shindig on the balcony,” Jesse pointed out.

But Shaynna Blaze didn’t care, and a small fake succulent on a coffee table really ground her gears.

“Come on, please … I’m taking off extra points for taking the piss with a fake plant,” she said. “This is ridiculous.”

“It’s lazy,” Neale Whittaker agreed. “It feels really lazy.”

“It’s meh,” Darren Palmer added before Shaynna threw one final bunch — “it’s boring as bat shit”.

Charming.

The pair cop two fives in the final judgment but Jesse claims “It’s water off a duck’s back”.

Unsurprisingly, Mark and Mitch take out the win, meaning they’ve won all the rooms on the third level.

They put a 12-seater dining table on their level 3 balcony, and decorated their second floor balcony with cane furniture and day bed. Their efforts get them three perfect 10s, the first of the season.

The only losers from the situation are their neighbours.

“You’re going to hear what’s going on on this veranda in house number two, and three, and four, and five,” Darren Palmer says. Cue pained smiles from their neighbours.

Next door, Tess and Luke are praised for their styling and furniture choice, particularly given the fact they’re flat broke. They’ve placed a high, narrow dining table right up against the balustrade, for eating breakfast while enjoying the views over St Kilda.

“It doesn’t have the pizzazz of next door, but it’s a very nice veranda,” Neale says.

Andy and Deb have gone against their usual beachy feel to match the industrial colours of their verandas, and it doesn’t pay off, with the judges saying that has created a disconnect with the rest of their house.

Andy, showing once again he’s the sweetest husband on The Block, will brook no criticism of his wife’s styling.

“It wasn’t good enough,” Deb says.

“It was for me,” Andy says. “You’re amazing.”

Matt and El’ise have presented two fairly bare spaces, and only get kudos for putting a game of Jenga in one of their verandas. An uncomfortable wooden bench divides the judges, with Darren Palmer the only fan.

“I wouldn’t even sit on this in a park,” Neale says.

Shaynna thinks the spaces are cold and formal.

Matt and El’ise had been considering using their bonus point this week, but the judges’ comments sink that idea. Their last room win was way back in week two, and with only three rooms to go, they’re on track to being one of The Block’s losingest couples.

Final scores:

Mitch and Mark 30

Tess and Luke 23.5

Andy and Deb 20.5

Matt and El’ise 20.5

Jesse and Mel 16.5
description: It was hard to tell the teams’ verandas apart, but that didn’t stop the judges slamming one “lazy” effort.
